Question_1.Context: The paper discusses the development of a novel e-skin with a unique pattern for mechanical stability and sweat permeability.
Question_1.Question: What is the purpose of the eyes-pattern in the e-skin?
Question_1.B: To improve mechanical stability and sweat permeability
Question_1.C: To increase the weight of the e-skin
Question_1.D: To reduce the flexibility of the e-skin
Question_1.Source: Our eyes-pattern, which was sophisticatedly designed by FEA simulation, exhibited the lowest localized stress of 943.3 MPa and strain of 43.1% compared to the previously reported patterns including auxetic kirigami and circular holes.

Question_2.Context: The paper mentions the importance of real-time monitoring of vital signs and the challenges faced by conventional devices.
Question_2.Question: Why is the accuracy of the sensing device crucial for real-time monitoring of vital signs?
Question_2.A: To ensure the device looks modern and sleek
Question_2.B: To prevent malfunctioning due to accumulation of skin by-products
Question_2.C: To increase the cost of the device
Question_2.Source: To investigate the suitability of the developed wearable sensor for real-time body temperature monitoring, the skin adherence test was performed for periodic exercise and rest cycles.

Question_3.Context: The paper discusses the experimental verification of the by-product permeability of the e-skin.
Question_3.Question: How was the by-product permeability of the e-skin experimentally confirmed?
Question_3.B: By comparing the color changes of litmus paper between different e-skins
Question_3.C: By measuring the weight of the e-skin before and after a workout
Question_3.D: By analyzing the electrical conductivity of the e-skin
Question_3.Source: The amount of sweat penetration was determined by comparing the color changes of the litmus paper between our e-skin and the conventional e-skin.

Question_4.Context: The paper describes the fabrication process of the patterned e-skin.
Question_4.Question: What material was used to fabricate the resistive temperature sensor in the e-skin?
Question_4.Source: Next, polyimide solution (PI, Sigma-Aldrich) was spin-coated onto the Si surface at 3000 rpm and baked sequentially at 110 ℃ (3 min), 130 ℃ (3 min), and 250 ℃ (1 h) to cure the film by evaporating the solvent.

Question_5.Context: The paper discusses the mechanical stability of the e-skin under bending conditions.
Question_5.Question: What was the minimum bending radius tested for the e-skin?
Question_5.Source: The bending curvature radius was accurately controlled from flat to 0.5 mm through the programmed codes in the bending motion system.

Question_6.Context: The paper highlights the importance of the eyes-pattern for stress relief in the e-skin.
Question_6.Question: What percentage lower was the localized stress in the eyes-pattern compared to the auxetic kirigami pattern?
Question_6.Source: the eyes-pattern exhibited a maximum localized stress of about 943.3 MPa, which was 48.7% and 60.8% lower than the auxetic kirigami (about 1839.9 MPa) and circular hole patterns (about 2408.8 MPa), respectively.

Question_7.Context: The paper discusses the real-time monitoring of body temperature using the resistive-type BTM sensor.
Question_7.Question: What was the resistance of the BTM sensor at a temperature of 90 ℃?
Question_7.Source: As the temperature increased from 20 ℃ to 90 ℃, the BTM sensor showed a linear increase in resistance from 204 Ω to 682 Ω.

Question_8.Context: The paper discusses the application of the e-skin for real-time body temperature monitoring.
Question_8.Question: What was the size of the wearable BTM sensor attached to the skin surface?
Question_8.Source: Figure 4b is a photograph of a 1 × 1 cm2-sized wearable BTM sensor attached to the skin surface of a human forearm.

Question_9.Context: The paper discusses the potential of the developed BTM sensor for replacing conventional body temperature monitoring systems.
Question_9.Question: What was the resistance of the BTM sensor during rest conditions?
Question_9.Source: During the repeated exercise, the wearable BTM sensor clearly exhibited the resistance difference between the exercise (325.6 Ω) and rest (281.5 Ω) conditions.

Question_10.Context: The paper concludes by emphasizing the potential of the eyes-patterned e-skin for real-time healthcare applications.
Question_10.Question: What is the main advantage of the eyes-patterned e-skin for real-time healthcare applications?
Question_10.A: Superior mechanical stability and by-products permeability
Question_10.Source: We believe that with our eyes-patterned e-skin, we may have proposed a new approach for reliable real-time healthcare applications.
